awd_titl_txt: CICI: Data Provenance: Data Quality and Security Evaluation Framework for Mobile Devices Platform
awd_abstract_narration:
Cyberinfrastructure advancements over the last decade laid a strong foundation for data generation and their communication on a staggering scale, opening up exciting opportunities for setting up a new collaboration between data providers and users, ordinary citizens and government or commercial agencies.  Nowadays, one can easily collect data via a mobile device's sensors and use a smartphone to report dangerous (for example, road slickness or construction hazard) conditions to a government agency. But not all data have equal quality, fidelity, and value. The data may originate from a poor quality camera. The high quality sensor data may be maliciously altered during its transfer over a network with low security. This project develops a framework to calculate integral data quality and security (DQS) indicators and provide them to the user along with data itself. This innovation has a high potential to significantly improve a wide spectrum of science and technology applications as it fuses different types of data based on a new quality and security information application. 

The project builds a proof-of-concept design platform to develop, verify and promote a comprehensive methodology for DQS evaluation. It focuses on the integration of cybersecurity metrics with other diverse metrics, such as accuracy, reliability, timeliness and safety, into a single methodological and technological framework. The framework includes generic data structures and algorithms implementing a DQS evaluation. While the developed evaluation techniques cover a wide range of data sources, from cloud based data systems to embedded sensors, the framework's implementation concentrates on using an ordinary user's Android smartphone. The developed methodologies will be verified by their implementation on the eNeighborhoodWatch platform, an application that not only enables interaction between users and government but also, with the user's permission, perform data collection for scientific studies (e.g. noise pollution, earthquake prediction), facilitating collaboration between thousands of ordinary users with the research community.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The project lays down a solid foundation for enhancing security of cyberinfrastructure, in particular, mobile devices, and improving data processing and data management techniques. It has developed the comprehensive data quality and security (DQS) evaluation framework that integrates a wide variety of DQS characteristics of multiple mobile devices and data sources incorporated therein, ranging from accuracy and completeness, to security and safety. To address the major changes and challenges in the cyberinfrastructure development over the last decade, the framework combines novel techniques and the tools, implementing them on mobile data collection devices and networks. The framework provides integral security and data quality indicators and makes the corresponding tools available to researchers, students and general public.

We investigated data quality and security evaluation techniques and their development with the knowledge graph application, examined a number of DQS metrics, and proposed and applied the calculus that integrated multiple metrics into aggregate indicators to be used in applications.

We conducted an empirical study of various mobile devices and collected data representing characteristics of sensors typically embedded into them and used the PAWR POWDER platform that allowed to evaluate the network and security characteristics influence on the data quality change over communication through networking facilities.

Our study allowed us to develop the knowledgebase of data generating wireless devices, focusing on mobile devices such as smartphones, wearable devices and tablets, typically used in wireless communication (see http://www.dataqualitylabs.com/downloadDataFor/Sensor%20Info). Moving beyond collecting data only, we employed our DQS evaluation techniques, processed the device characteristics, produced SDQ metrics and incorporated them into our knowledge base. In total, we considered a few thousand devices produced by over a hundred manufacturers with about 58 characteristic attributes for these devices. Our current collection contains data on 19 sensor types including accelerometer, barometer, gesture, humidity, face id and fingerprint sensor (rear, side, under display and in front), temperature, ambient light, gyroscope, heart rate, compass, iris scanner, proximity, and color spectrum sensors. In this research, we selected and further analyzed five the most popular sensor types: 52 accelerometers brands, 14 gyroscopes brands, 20 proximity sensor brands, five barometers, and 16 compass sensors brands.

We developed novel methodologies and produced a tool-set for the data quality and security evaluation of wireless Android mobile devices. Almost one thousand users in multiple countries from around the world (based on statistics provided by Google) have already tried and installed these applications on their devices that proves the significance of this project results for improving the cyberinfrastructure data quality and security.

One PhD and 45 MS in Computer Science students, whose work contributed to this project, defended their projects/theses on the corresponding topics and graduated to the workforce, both in academia and industry. The book, incorporating many project results, is prepared for publication by the PI (L. Reznik ?Intelligent security systems: How artificial intelligence, machine learning and data science work for and against computer security?, IEEE Press - Wiley&Sons, ISBN-978-1119771531). It is expected to be used by numerous students and professionals across various computer and security related disciplines and courses. Also, we produced 25 other peer-reviewed publications and delivered eight other presentations at professional conferences.

 


Last Modified: 10/06/2021
Modified by: Leon Reznik
